2009/11/29 Richard Gong <gongrichard@...>
>
>
> In my mind, this algorithm would use localized learning rules, and grow neurons/connections in an organic manner (like NEAT but
> the connections are added as the brain experiences the world).
>
> The closest thing I know of is George Hinton's restricted boltzmann machine, but it doesn't really grow organically -- network
> structure has to be pre-defined, and also has to be layered.

It's a pretty good question but I don't know of any such work being
done. BTW I think you mean /Geoffrey/ Hinton, I was going suggest you
look at his RBM work. You're right that RBMs don't grow, not unless
there's some later work I'm unaware of. Makes me wonder if another
interesting approach would be to evolve simple rules for modifying
networks (including structure changes) in an attempt to find such a
system. Sort of like a set of co-evolved Genetic Programs that operate
on networks and change their structure and weights.

If we look at human brains then babies start out with pretty big
brains so it would seem there's some degree of 'blank canvas' to that
strategy - trim away unused connections and strengthen used ones, as
oppsed to starting minimally and building up. But then I'm assuming
that the sensory input in the womb isn't enough to /start/ building a
model of the world - which is almost certainly wrong, to some extent
anyway.

But yeh, it's an interesting question.

Colin
